settings.text: Dressing for scorching temperatures on holiday is a breeze, but heading into an office can often complicate matters. To help you dress appropriately and maintain your flawless style whatever the weather, we present our seven summer workwear must-haves...

settings.grid-content:
I started Tatiana Alida Design three years ago in 2018 and only recently took the decision to work on the brand full-time. My strengths have always been in art and design and at university it just seemed like the natural step to pursue exactly that. I honestly couldn’t imagine doing anything else.


How would you describe your aesthetic? 

I would describe my work as colourful, whimsical, and feminine. I use watercolour, acrylic, pen, paper, paint, clay, fabrics, and my iPad, but really there is no limit to the materials I like to use and experiment with.


What or who inspires your work?

I am inspired by a lot of artists, interior design, and film. I have also always had journals and collected artefacts from my life sort of like a personal archive. I look through these folders when I need to find inspiration and that really helps.

How would you describe your workspace? What items on your desk can you not work without?

Busy! I have a lot of different items and pieces on my desk in my studio that hold importance to me. I have a crystal on my desk which I am constantly reaching for, lots of cactus plants in pots that I hand painted and my pretty pink Liberty floral notebook which I use to jot down all my ideas. Then all my studio walls are covered up with different mood boards from current projects I am working on as well as lots of colourful postcards, doodles and artwork pinned up everywhere.
settings.image-caption: I created this illustration for Chinti & Parker, a colourful and summer-inspired piece of work, to go with the season and to complement the wonderfully bright and uplifting clothes. I particularly loved wearing this yellow set.

settings.text:
How were you introduced to Chinti & Parker and why is the brand such a good fit for Women for Women International?

We’ve been working with Chinti & Parker since 2018, when the brand launched a collection in aid of Women for Women International. I love the fact that the brand is the brainchild of two women, Anna and Rachael, who have an inherent understanding of what women want to feel and look good in. This is so reflective of the women who go through our programme. Many of them become successful entrepreneurs or work together in embroidery / craft cooperatives.

settings.grid-content:
Aside from your art, do you have any other creative outlets?

Yes, I enjoy cooking and love reading. I have just started Where the Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens – my mother sent it to me the other day as she loved it so much and can’t stop talking about it. But my most favourite creative outlet is having a coffee or cocktails with friends out in Soho and going to the Royal Academy or National Portrait Gallery. I try once a week to go to an exhibition or gallery and I find viewing other art so inspiring. I spend a lot of time alone working in my studio so for me to be out and about in the bustling city centre taking in all the lively surroundings, people’s outfits and interiors (in normal circumstances) inspires me and gives me a real buzz.

What would you say to anyone looking to find a new creative outlet?

Order some air-drying clay and make little tea light holders, a paper weight perhaps. You could also get a sketchbook and a few nice crayons and just start drawing. Have fun with it that’s my only rule.

Do you have any daily rituals to help creativity flow?

Yes, I write down all the things I have accomplished each day, even the small things and read them over and as silly as it sounds, I give myself a well done pat on the back. Music is very important as well, I know there are certain songs that make me feel good… Abba, S Club 7 and Dolly Parton are always playing in my studio. If I listen to one sad song it can completely ruin my workflow for the day. No Adele or Cat Stevens allowed.

What do you love about the Chinti & Parker outfit you chose?

I love the yellow polo as it sort of reminds me of a vintage tennis top. The yellow skirt is bold and fun, and I think can be work with chunky trainers in the day or a summer evening with sling-backs... Yellow is just the happiest colour.
